--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> 1) A tree based genome. This helps in a few different ways. When 
> crossover occurs we only swap nodes that are co-located on both
parents. 
> It also allows us to implement a 'reference' node (more later). And
it 
> allow us to mutate the genome by not only mutating data within a
node, 
> but by copying, deleting and moving branches of the tree around. By 
> relating nodes in a tree and branchies of the tree I thought I
would 
> facilitate more intelligent, meaningful manipualtion of the genome.
> 

Hi Colin...what does "co-located" mean if you are looking at two
different trees?  Isn't there still a topology-matching problem
with trees?  How do you know which branches match up?

> 2) Each node either represents a neuron or a reference. Neurons
have a 
> position, which is relative to the parent node. They also have a
list of 
> (incoming) connections. Each connection has a length (thus giving a 
> position to connect to, relative to the neuron's position) and a 
> weight. The networks evolved thus have fixed weights. Also note
that 
> connections connect to the nearest neuron, therefore the connection 
> length does not have to be precise, or even anywhere near a neuron.
 
> Where a neuron is a child of a reference node there is a highly 
> convoluted technique whereby I  evolving a connection point onto
the 
> parent tree. In theory this allows re-used parts of the tree to be 
> extended further (variation on reused genes). In hindsight it is a
very 
> poor implementation.
> 
> 3) Reference nodes. A node on the tree that cause traversal to jump
to 
> some other specified point. The reference itself is just a list of 
> numbers, each number is basically a list of child indexes
specifying a 
> path to the referenced node through the tree starting from the root 
> node. Later I also implemented relative references where a child
index 
> of -1 means to traverse back up the tree one node. Reference nodes
allow 
> for the possibility of re-use and therefore aid in evolving
complexity.
> 

Gruau's Cellular Encoding (CE) also uses a tree genome and can reuse
nodes in the tree.  Have you looked at CE?  I describe it (and give a
picture) in our Taxonomy for Artificial Embryogeny paper:

http://steam.csres.utexas.edu/nn/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pubs)=PubID&PubID(Pubs)=121

The references to Gruau's original papers on CE are also given in that
paper.  It might be interesting to see how your ideas are similar to
Gruau's.

ken
